docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Aug. 17 news article on the decline in New York City's Medicaid rolls highlights a key conflict between Medicaid and welfare policy in the city. Significant decreases in the city's welfare rolls have contributed to a tremendous increase in the number of children and adults in the city without health insurance. According to one study, 17 percent of New York City's children are uninsured.

headline.main: Sometimes the Homeless Are the Working Poor

docs.abstract: Letter by Nancy Solomon, chairwoman of Citizens Committee for Children, says Aug 17 article on decline in New York City's Medicaid rolls highlights key conflict between Medicaid and welfare policy in the city, and large number of children have been left without health insurance coverage
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your Aug. 17 news article on the decline in New York City's Medicaid rolls highlights a key conflict between Medicaid and welfare policy in the city. Significant decreases in the city's welfare rolls have contributed to a tremendous...

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Green, a Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from New York, called yesterday for substantial cuts in Pentagon spending over the next five years, saying the nation was wasting money on defense that should instead go to school construction, health care for children and other domestic initiatives. Mr. Green, the New York City Public Advocate and one of the three major Democratic candidates seeking to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato this fall, asserted that the Pentagon was relying on an outdated view of the world in determining the nation's defense needs.

headline.main: Green Urges Cuts in Defense To Finance Social Programs

docs.abstract: Public Advocate Mark Green, Democratic candidate for US Senate, calls for substantial cuts in Pentagon spending over next five years; says nation is wasting money on defense that should instead go to domestic initiatives; says his defense cuts would save $100 billion over next five years and not jeopardize national security (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors charged an elected school board member in northern Rockland County yesterday with receiving $107,000 in kickbacks from the broker who arranged health insurance coverage for the district's employees. A Federal complaint announced by Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, charged Kevin Lynch, 40, a member of the Haverstraw-Stony Point Central School District, with one count of mail fraud. The charge carries a maximum sentence of five years in prison.

headline.main: School Board Member Is Charged in Kickbacks

docs.lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Smith, a 40-year-old hotel maid, knows all too well the hard reality that lies behind this alluring city's tourism boom. While the city's hotels command premium rates, thousands of workers who carry the industry on their backs -- housekeepers, banquet waiters and laundry-room employees -- work for wages that keep them below the poverty line. Ms. Smith earns $5.98 an hour cleaning rooms at the Wyndham Hotel. The $700 a month she takes home is hardly enough to support her three children.

headline.main: Labor Eyes a Prize: Hotels of New Orleans

docs.lead_paragraph: A state judicial panel has voted to rebuke a Bronx judge, ruling that he had violated regulations by appearing on a television show to discuss the civil case against O.J. Simpson, and by engaging in two other instances of inappropriate behavior. The panel, the Commission on Judicial Conduct, said yesterday that it had decided to censure Justice Douglas E. McKeon of State Supreme Court. A censure, which is the stiffest punishment short of removal from the bench, does not affect the authority of a judge, but is considered a stain on his or her record.

headline.main: Comments About O.J. Simpson Bring Censure for Bronx Judge

docs.snippet: A state judicial panel has voted to rebuke a Bronx judge, ruling that he had violated regulations by appearing on a television show to discuss the civil case against O.J. Simpson, and by engaging in two other instances of inappropriate behavior.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a trend that has alarmed health care providers, the number of poor people enrolled in Medicaid in New York State has been declining for the last three years. While the strong economy may account for some of the drop, many analysts say the decline is, in part, a side effect of the overhaul of the nation's welfare system in late 1996, legislation that was intended to move recipients into the work force.

headline.main: Medicaid Rolls Have Declined In Last 3 Years

docs.abstract: Number of poor people enrolled in Medicaid in New York State has been declining for last three years in trend that has alarmed health care providers; analysts say that decline is in part side effect of overhaul of nation's welfare system in late 1996, legislation that was intended to move recipients into work force; say that when Congress drafted overhaul, it took pains to spell out that people no longer entitled to welfare, particularly children, would continue to be eligible for Medicaid; say people who have been removed from welfare or discouraged from applying have also been swept from Medicaid rolls; number of poor people enrolled in Medicaid in NYS declined 26 percent, to 1.28 million, between Jan 1995 and Jan 1998 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Possible Nuclear Facility Detected in North Korea United States intelligence agencies have detected a huge, secret underground facility in North Korea that they believe is the centerpiece of an effort to revive the country's frozen nuclear weapons program, according to officials who have been briefed on the intelligence data. A1 Progress in Africa Bomb Case Law-enforcement officials investigating the bombings at the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania expressed optimism that a man brought back to the Kenyan capital after being detained in Pakistan will help the authorities unravel the plot behind the deadly terrorist attacks. The officials said that one or two other men also suspected of complicity in the bombings were in custody in Pakistan. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Cynthia Salomon was 7 months' pregnant when her husband, Jose Lazo, was diagnosed with testicular cancer. It was Jan. 8, their daughter's second birthday. They had three jobs between them -- he cooked in two restaurants, she answered the telephone in a bank. But by Feb. 3, after his first operation, she was just another applicant for relief and Medicaid at the East End Income Support Center. Ms. Salomon waited for hours at the Manhattan welfare center, only to be sent home to call for an appointment. She called 15 times a day to get through. She submitted hospital records, rent receipts, birth certificates and bank statements, dealing with caseworkers trained to push people to work.

headline.main: Illness, a New Baby, and Then a Struggle for Assistance

docs.abstract: Article on difficulty that Cynthia Salomon and Jose Lazo of East Harlem had in getting Medicaid assistance after he was diagnosed with testicular cancer and she had baby (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: U S West and union representatives held no talks today on the first day of a strike that followed two days of negotiations with a Federal mediator. The 34,000 members of the Communications Workers of America are on strike against U S West, a regional Bell based in Denver that provides telephone service to 25 million customers in 14 states. The workers, who represent more than half of the company's 51,000 employees, walked off the job at midnight. They include operators, customer service representatives and field technicians, whose three-year contract expired today.

headline.main: 34,000 Telephone Workers On Strike Against U S West

docs.abstract: Communications Workers of American and US West hold no talks on first day of strike following failure of Federal mediation efforts; 34,000 union members represent regional Bell based in Denver that provides telephone service to 25 million customers in 14 states; issues in walkout discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rebuffed by a Federal court in their effort to regulate tobacco products, Clinton Administration officials said today that they were seriously considering lawsuits against cigarette companies to recover money spent by the Federal Government to treat smokers under Medicare and other Federal health programs. Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, has repeatedly urged the Administration to file such suits, but White House and Justice Department officials expressed little interest until a comprehensive tobacco bill died in the Senate in June.

headline.main: U.S. May Sue Big Tobacco For Care Costs

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration, rebuffed by Federal court in effort to regulate tobacco products, weighs lawsuits against cigarette companies to recover money spent by Federal Government to treat smokers under Medicare and other Federal health programs (M)
